I think the problem with Morde is he gets countered too easily with simple strategies. Force him to trade and he will push the lane, all his abilities except his ult deal damage to multiple targets. Eventually he will push and just call for a gank, there is not much he can do. To counter these weaknesses he is given damage (it was a lot in his heyday but now it isnt worth much) that is easy to hit. So if you do nothing about him he will push you to your turret and kill you at the same time without you being able to do anything about it. If you dont know how to deal with Morde then you are going to get crushed even by someone using him for the first time.  

Neither of these promote healthy gameplay, either you are miserable or your enemy is miserable.

I usually rush Will of the Ancients, it stops him from losing health and if you hit a big wave of minions you gain some back. Then Rabadons (sometimes ill build WotG then DFG then Deathcap then Rylais, the order depends on the game). Sorc boots, if i didnt build DFG earlier i will build it now, it is core late game item.  

His passive, rylais, and Visage is all i need for health usually.

Some of the key questions we ask when deciding which champions to do updates on:



**How badly does this champion need a visual/audio update? **

The more out of place (or out of date) they currently look/sound the more reason we have to rework them. A champion that gets played a lot and really needs a visual upgrade is particularly significant - since they're in games a lot they'll be seen a lot and therefore contribute substantially to the overall average visual quality of the game. Tristana's a good example of this - she's a popular character, who's also really easy to acquire (Facebook or 1350IP), with quite a few visual/audio upgrade needs.   


**How problematic is this champion's gameplay?**

Champions with a lack of counterplay, that result in degenerate lane picks, that suppress interesting play etc can be rework priorities because they make the game worse overall. Xerath and Soraka are good examples of this category.


**How much untapped potential does this champion have?**

These are characters with cool themes that aren't properly executed on, unsatisfying kits etc. Stuff that could be really cool, but isn't, usually for a number of reasons (gameplay+aesthetics+personality for example). There's a good seed of a champion in there, but it's not done right. Sion's the best example of this.

So then why are Yorick and Urgot so low on the priority list? Lee Sin fits the second question, and to be blunt, there are a few champions that fans considered to have received poor reworks based on your standards. Eve, Olaf, and even Xerath.

Yorick/Urgot - Both Sion levels of rework in terms of amount of work. We talked a lot about which champion was the best fit for that level of update next and conclusion we came to was Poppy was the best overall choice. Lot of good points in favor of Yorick, and especially Urgot, but Poppy felt like the best choice for the next slot. 

Lee Sin - We feel his problem's that he's a generalist who crowds out other picks if you've got a player able to take proper advantage of him. That means the work he needs is a combination of accentuating (or creating) weaknesses (and potentially strengths) and possibly a bit more counterplay. Some of that work at least's going to be an issue of balance, as much or more than rework. 

Eve/Olaf - Could do with some work, agreed. I don't personally feel Olaf's too far off being playable, amount he leaves some champions without options when he's strong though's pretty problematic.

Xerath - I'll have to disagree with you on Xerath, I feel his rework overall left him in a pretty good spot. Would be nice to improve the visual satisfaction on his ult at some point though, the current visual effect was designed for a somewhat different style of ult so doesn't sync up well with the feel of the current gameplay.

@Meddler: I agree that Poppy is the most problematic champion and need a rework ASAP. However, as a Urgot player, I fear I'll have to wait another one or two years for his rework. Are my worries justified? I just would like to know, so I resign myself .__.
Me too.

Honestly, I'm not sure Xerath's ult is even worth using most of the time. His Q feels a lot more satisfying, both in terms of damage and being able to hit a target. An ultimate that never lands may as well never exist.

I'm not sure if changing his ult would be a live balance team or a rework team task. Does it just depend on how much is done?

Hey,

As a person who mains Urgot (and there is really not many) I thought that you would want to hear an input from such a player to contribute to your update plans. In my opinion Urgot's kit is very fun and there is a lot of potential with item, ability synergies and combos. If played right he is a very good lane bully and can definitely do well late game. You say here that you would like to make some adjustments to this champion so I think this is a good opportunity for me to voice my opinion

I asked a bunch of league players why they don't want to play Urgot. Most people have said that it is because he looks ugly. A visual change to him to make him look more fancy and/or have more flashy abilities with perhaps contrasts of blue would be quite nice and could encourage people to play him. Something to make his play style more pronounced.

When it comes to updating his skill set I really do not think it needs changing like Sion's did as it could potentially break the champion. He is one of the best lane bullies and also a great duelist; playing against him is quite a unique experience especially if you do not have mobility or sustain. If you are going to change anything please keep that in mind. Perhaps his role needs to be made more clear to the players so that after trying him they will not get discouraged (likewise with Yorick he has a lot of potential but people do not know how to play as him resulting in them giving up on further attempts).

When it comes to re-balancing so that he can fit in more with the current meta I would say that his E (Noxxian Corrosive Charge) should make enemies visible for the duration since the Q (Acid Hunter) locks on no matter what even when the enemy is stealth. Having the champion visible would be a nice buff so that the player won't have to be guessing where to put his mouse when he uses his Q. In team fights his job is to focus high priority targets so perhaps more burst synergy with his ultimate would be nice on top of the current additional armor and magic resist (perhaps the ultimate could apply the same effect as the Noxxian Corrosive Charge).

In conclusion, Urgot is a viable champion in the current meta and the changes that are made I suggest small utility tweaks being added to his kit. He should definitely receive a skin update but his main role of a lane bully should remain unchanged as it is quite unique and interesting in the way it is executed. Thanks for reading and please don't break the champion. I am a real fan of old and underplayed champions so feel free to ask me about anything involving this champion I would be more than happy to answer.

Best Regards from,
Asothin - EU Nordic and East

I don't think Yorick needs a complete rework. And I sure as hell am certain that Urgot doesn't need one.

Urgot is extremely fun to play. It's not a point and click champion, which was the reason that Riot gave when they were justifying reworking Sion, and Ryze and Warwick.

And being fun isn't the only reason that justifies him not needing a "complete relaunch".
First of all, he only needs balance changes. When he was released he was super strong, and there is a middle term between broken and garbage.
And the most important reason for Urgot not need a rework is: "RIOT has to STOP treating Urgot like an ADC!"

If you keep trying to balance a champion to do something he isn't supposed to do, of course you'll fail. It would be the same thing as putting Gnar in bot lane, tag him as "marksman", and then complaining he just gets wrecked by other ADCs and thinking he needs a rework.
Urgot isn't an ADC, and I don't understand why can't Riot realize that. Riot realized Teemo wasn't an ADC a while ago, even though he's tagged as "marksman", which made it possible for him to be balanced, because he stopped being looked at as being matched up against an ADC in lane.

Also, about Xerath: I played Xerath since I started playing the game. I did nothing but play Xerath for my first year of this game. I loved it, I got his two skins, and when he got reworked, my skins never saw the light of day again.
It looked boring before testing it, but I didn't want to complain without trying him out, but after a week of playing new Xerath, I confirmed my suspissions. Xerath became just straight up boring, no other word to describe him.
Anyone that has fun playing new Xerath, I'm happy for you, but I'm certain you never tried, or at least played well, the old Xerath.

I don't approve of reworking champions, but I understand Riot's point about it, and I accepted it. But what I don't understand is why they rework champions that are 2 years old and have nice mechanics, to leave the ones they hate (the point and click ones) wondering around for ages.
And I say this because I know about the plans of reworking champions like Fiora and LeBlanc. And while Fiora, even though not old, is a bit of point and click with no counterplay, I absolutely don't understand the idea behind LeBlanc rework.
LeBlanc is one of the most highly mechanical champions, which although strong, is not broken. Especially after the silence was removed.
There is absolutely no reason to rework LeBlanc, but, and every time I say this it pains me a little, but I've got used to these non-sense ideas from Riot. And it pains me to say this because Riot is the best company in the world, and the company I love the most.
